newsitem.title: UK: UK chemical industry says EU work rules "flexible".
newsitem.headline: UK chemical industry says EU work rules "flexible".

text.p: Representatives of Britain's chemical industry said on Thursday that "there are many opportunities for flexible interpretation" of European Union (EU) laws limiting working hours and guaranteeing rest breaks.
Last November the European Court of Justice rejected a British government challenge to the EU's working time directive, which sets a maximum average working week of 48 hours.

In its response to the Department of Trade and Industry's (DTI) consultation exercise on implementing the directive, the Chemical Industry Association (CIA) said the government should "take full advantage" of flexible interpretation of the rules.
"One example is the flexibility which permits employers to make agreements with their employees if they wish to work longer than the maximum 48-hour week," the CIA said.
It said this would allow employers and employees to "come to mutually-agreed sensible arrangements on how best to organise the working day."

The CIA also welcomed the government's statement that it would frame British legislation "to reflect the current labour market and existing work practices which are needed if UK industry is to be competitive."

The association noted that most of its member companies had working weeks of 38 hours or less, and it therefore expected that agreements to exceed the 48-hour maximum "will be less prevalent than in other sectors."
It said it also anticipated little difficulty over minimum paid leave entitlements, saying most of its members "comfortably" exceeded the directive's requirements.
